misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Sorting changes one array but “keeps” parallel arrays aligned automatically
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if they sort the scores array, the corresponding names array will still match those scores (i.e., the name-score pairing is preserved automatically).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `Arrays.sort(z)` only reorders the elements in the `z` array. It does not know that `y` is a parallel array that must be permuted in the same way. After sorting `z`, the indices of scores no longer correspond to the same students’ names in `y`, so using `y[n-1]` with `z[n-1]` is mixing unrelated data.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: prints a correct highest score (because `z[n-1]` is max after sort) but may print the wrong student name (because `y[n-1]` is just the last-entered name, not the name associated with the max score).

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel Array Index Correspondence After Independent Sorting
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when you sort one of two parallel arrays independently, the indices will magically stay synchronized with the other array. They think sorting the scores array will cause the names array to automatically rearrange in matching positions, or that the last index of scores will correspond to the last index of names with the correct pairing.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student does not understand that sorting a single array breaks the index correspondence between parallel arrays. In Java, Arrays.sort(z) only sorts the scores array in place. The names array remains unchanged. After sorting, z[n-1] contains the highest score, but y[n-1] is still the last name that was entered—not necessarily the name of the student with the highest score. Parallel arrays require synchronized sorting (swapping elements in both arrays together) to maintain their relationship.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: the program will print the last entered name paired with the highest score, rather than the correct student's name with the highest score. For the sample input, it will output 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of 'Top student: Bob (92)'.

evidence.code_snippet: Arrays.sort(z); // Only sorts the scores array, not the names array

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because the 'names' and 'scores' arrays are logically related and were populated using the same indices, performing a sort operation on one will automatically trigger a corresponding reordering of the other to keep the data pairs synchronized.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In the actual Java execution model, parallel arrays are entirely independent objects in memory. The Arrays.sort() method only has a reference to the specific array passed to it and does not have any semantic knowledge that index 'i' in the scores array is linked to index 'i' in the names array. Consequently, the relationship between the name and the score is destroyed when only one array is sorted.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel-array coupling illusion (sorting one array magically reorders the other)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because `names` and `scores` are "parallel arrays" (same length, same indices), sorting the `scores` array will keep the name-score pairing intact, so the name at index `n-1` will still belong to the highest score after sorting.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects. `Arrays.sort(z)` reorders only the elements of `z` (in place) and does not (and cannot) automatically move elements in `y`. After sorting `z`, the index positions in `z` no longer correspond to the original student indices in `y`, so `y[n-1]` is just the last-entered name, not necessarily the top scorer’s name.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: prints the maximum score correctly (`z[n-1]`) but often prints the wrong student name (`y[n-1]`).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting only the scores array (z) will automatically preserve the correspondence between names and scores, so that the highest score will still be paired with the correct name.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Arrays.sort() rearranges elements within a single array; it has no awareness of parallel arrays or their relationships. When z is sorted, only the score values move to new positions. The names array (y) remains unchanged, so the indices no longer correspond. The student failed to recognize that with parallel arrays, sorting one array without synchronizing the other breaks the name-score pairing. They would need to either: (1) track indices during sorting, (2) swap elements in both arrays together, or (3) use objects/records to keep data together.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: For the sample input (Alice 85, Bob 92, Charlie 78), after sorting z becomes [78, 85, 92]. The code prints y[n-1] (Charlie) paired with z[n-1] (92), producing 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of the correct 'Top student: Bob (92)'.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that since two arrays were populated at the same indices in parallel loops, they are intrinsically linked by the computer. They assume that an operation like sorting the 'scores' array will automatically trigger a corresponding reordering of the 'names' array to maintain the established relationships.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student fails to understand that arrays in Java are independent objects in memory. The 'parallel' relationship is a conceptual strategy implemented by the programmer, not a feature of the language's execution model. The Arrays.sort() method only has access to the single array passed to it and cannot observe or modify unrelated arrays.
